newsitem.title: USA: NASD unit eyes bias case aribitration procedures.
newsitem.headline: NASD unit eyes bias case aribitration procedures.

text.p: The National Association of Securities Dealers' top regulator, Mary Schapiro, said on Thursday her group is considering ways to improve how employees of securities firms can bring discrimination cases.

"We've got to make some decision about this issue. We think in the next two months," Mary Schapiro, head of NASD Regulation, told Reuters. Schapiro said NASD Regulation is considering several options which may include modifying the standard form, called U-4, which employees must sign agreeing that all cases be arbitrated rather than taken to court. That also includes discrimination cases.
"There are a wide range of options. One is not to do anything," Schapiro said, adding that the NASD has already taken many steps to improve the arbitration process.
But Schapiro maintained that NASD will continue to improve its arbitration process, particularly when it comes to discrimination cases.

The issue has become a top priority for the securities industry's self-regulator, even though in 1996 discrimination cases accounted for less than two percent of the total cases arbitrated at the NASD.
According to a spokeswoman, there were 5,631 cases arbitrated at NASD, of which only 109 were discrimination cases.
But arbitrators involved in discrimination cases are generally more versed in securities laws than discrimination issues.
"I think no matter what we decide to do there are improvements to the arbitration program for employment discrimination claims that we want to make no matter what," Schapiro said.
The regulator's plans would at least include greater diversity in the arbitrator pool and better training, Schapiro said.
To help make a decision over the next two months, NASD Regulation has created a special group to act as a "sounding board," a spokeswoman said.

That group includes: Ellen Brown, Maryland's former state securities regulator; Gertrude Michelson, a labor attorney and governor of the American Stock Exchange; Pauline Schneider, a Washington attorney; Alfred Osborne, a professor at UCLA's Graduate School of Management; Mark Sargent, dean of Villanova University's school of law; and Theodore Levine, PaineWebber Inc's general counsel.
